The object of the present Bill is to make permanent and to amend the Wireless Telegraphy Act 1904,, The Aotof 1904- was regarded as cf an experimental character and was limited in duration. It has bean extended fromtime to time by the Expiring Laws Continuance Act, and,unless further extended, comes to an end,on the 31stDecember next. It has been felt for a long time thatthe act should he amended in csrtain particulars and made permanent', and a Bill on the general lines of thepresent Bill passed the Committee stage in the Houseof Commons in 19S3, but was then dropped owing to the dissolution. The Act of 1904 was necessary because the PostmasterGeneral's powers of control under his ordinary telegraphmonopoly do not extend to wireless stations intended for communication outside this country, or to wireless stations intended for communication of a purely privatecharacter (e.g. between the different branches of thesame firm)0 Such powers of control were necessary,first from a strategic point of view, and secondly vbecause,.in the absence cf control, chaos would inevitablyhave resulted owing to the interference of one stationwith another. All civilised nations have found itnecessary to exercise such control, and in some countries the control is much more stringent than ;here. The principal amendments of the original Act includedin the present Bill are as followsj- (l) Certain, points of doubt which have arisen under the principal Act are removed. These Cl. 4 (1)ciai (2) K 7 $ These relate to the questions (a) whether the maintenance1 of a wireless station without the Postmaster General's lioence, as distinct from its installation or use, is an offence; (b) whether a licence is necessary for a reoeiving station as distinct from a transmitting station; and (c) whether the Postmaster General has power to charge a reasonable fee to coverCl. 5 expenses in connection with the grant of experimental licences. The Postmaster General has been proceeding in the past on the assumption that he has these powers under,the original Act, and he is advised that he has proceeded correctly, but these is a certain element of doubt in each case whioh it is desirable to remove.' This is particularly important as regards the necessity of a lioence for a receiving station, as the broadcasting scheme as a whole depends upon the Postmaster General1s powers in this respect.Cl. 2, (2) The provisions of the principal Aotregarding ships are extended to aircraft. (3) The provisions of the principal Act are extended to the installation and workingCl, 9. of apparatus for the wireless transmission of energy as distinct from messages. This is necessary because the same interference results whatever may be the purpose for which the etherio '.etherio waves are used. This amendment hasbeen discussed with representatives of theRailway Companies and with the ElectricityCommiasioners, and has been agreed to by then, (4) Penalties are imposed for thegeliding of false or misleading signals of distress; for the improper divulging of wireless messages overheard by persons for whom they are not intended; and for the transmission of indecent or offensive messagesor messages "subversive of public order",It JiB right to mention that there was practically no controversy during theCommittee stage of the Bill of 1922 exceptupon the latter provision,, (S) Provision is made for simplifyingthe arrangements for more stringent control incase of national emergency. The PostmasterGeneral is given power in such an event tomake ouch rules as he may consider necessary with regard to the possession and. sale of apparatus, as well as its installation and use, (6) An amendment, giving the PostnssterGeneral power to accept compromise fines inoases of minor default as an alternative toprosecution. This has been made at thesuggestion of the Broadcasting Committee oflast yean, in order to facilitate thetreatment of cases of evasion of licences inconnection with the broadcasting scheme. (7) (7) At tha suggestion of the admiralty the provisions of the principal Act have been extended to visual or sound signalling stations(other than lloyd signalling stations orstations under the control of the Board ofTrade or Lighthouse Authorities) used or intended to he used for the purpose ofcommunication with ships at sea.. The object is to prevent the establishment of illicitstations of this description whioh might beused for the purpose of communication withthe enemy in case of war. V.
